author: China Insights
description:
On October 13, 2025, at the Global Women’s Summit in Beijing, a single camera shot stunned the room—China’s First Lady Peng Liyuan appeared in all black. She didn’t speak, yet it felt like she was “sending a signal.” Three months earlier she had greeted leaders at the SCO Summit in a white dress with a smile; now she had switched to a stark black ensemble. Foreign media commented: “This isn’t fashion; it’s the isotherm of a political climate shift.” Black—mourning, or control? Between white and black lies an unspoken narrative of Chinese politics. Don’t miss the next drop—subscribe and enable the bell.

title: First Lady in Black: Peng Liyuan’s Style Shift Shakes Zhongnanhai

author: China Insights
description:
Counting on our fingers, it’s been more than a month since Yu Menglong’s mysterious fall to his death, and the tsunami of public opinion it triggered is still surging. On the Chinese mainland, a rare wave of “storming the tower” by the whole populace has appeared—people are going head-to-head with the powerful and determined to “lift Yu Menglong up.” The more the CCP censors and suppresses, the more everyone looks for ways to break through, flooding the screens with bullet comments demanding that a case be officially opened. You could say Gen Z has really made people sit up and take notice.

title: Yu Menglong Effect Erupts: “Run!” Warnings Go Globa

author: China Insights
description:
The CCP’s Fourth Plenum hasn’t even begun, and China is already in a “civil war.” Faith is locked down, petitioners are seized, black money flees, hospitals shut their doors—95-year-olds are surveilled, pastors are taken away, overseas students are pulled into money-laundering webs, and doctors switch to food delivery. Four fronts fracture at once; a regime’s fear spins out of control. Don’t miss the next drop—subscribe and enable the bell.

title: China on Edge: Faith, Surveillance, Money, Medicine

author: China Insights
description:
Shenzhen Metro and Vanke’s “dual-chairman” Xin Jie has mysteriously gone missing for 23 days—behind it lies a web of “red capital” reaching up to the CCP’s very top! At the same time, The Economist revealed: in China, “on average one entrepreneur disappears every week,” plunging the business world into fear and a wave of flight. This storm may be the beginning of the collapse of the CCP’s red-elite system.Welcome to China Insights — your window into the real China, beyond the veil.

title: One a Week? The Economist’s Alarming China Stat

author: China Insights
description:
A birthday livestream should have been a happy occasion. But just as Guo Junchen smiled and cut the cake, the next second he made a “help” gesture, and there on the table sat five blood-red longevity peaches—homophonically hinting at “no way out.” Stranger still, he and Yu Menglong belong to the same agency and are both tied to the same class of “arms/fireworks” trademarks!
